Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: This morning, I woke up to a flurry of texts from my spouse, reminding me that her parents would be arriving in the afternoon. The house was a mess—dishes piled up, laundry scattered, and the guest room still needed fresh sheets. She expected me to help, to share the load, and to make sure everything was perfect for their visit. I promised I’d be home early to help, but as I was about to leave for work, my phone buzzed again. It was a message from the volunteer coordinator: “Please remember, everyone must stay for the full shift today. We need all hands on deck to implement the new safety procedures.” I knew how important these changes were, especially after last week’s incident. The coordinator was counting on me to set an example. My stomach twisted as I stared at the two messages, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me. I wanted to be reliable at home and responsible at the shelter, but I couldn’t see how I could possibly do both.
